data.title: Virtual Health & Well-Being for Students
data.meta_description: Provide your college and university community with access to 24/7 mental health, medical and self-care resources.
data.text:
Higher Ed's Most Trusted Virtual Care Provider

Colleges and universities trust TimelyCare to provide complete clinical care, advanced technology, and expert guidance to support students, faculty, and staff. Let’s work together to create a healthier campus through a connected system of care.

Does Your School Have TimelyCare?

Access Care Now!

Create a Healthier Campus Through a Connected System of Care

Whole Student Health

From mental health to medical care, TimelyCare provides the virtual care students need.

Diverse Provider Network

TimelyCare’s culturally responsive provider network reflects the diversity of your campus community.

A Team-Based Approach

TimelyCare uses care coordination and virtual health to complement your existing campus healthcare resources.

Complete Clinical Care

Combine health and well-being on a single virtual platform through phone, video, or video chat.

Built for Digital Natives

Empower students to create their own path to care while emphasizing agency, speed, and personal choice.

Expert Guidance and Support

Our higher education experts will help launch your program and drive student engagement.

Higher Education Trusts TimelyCare

As demand for support continues to grow, how can your campus resources keep up?

In our work with millions of students at more than 350 colleges and universities across the country, our team applies that experience to develop a truly complete virtual health and well-being solution that complements your campus resources with:

24/7 Support

50-State Coverage

Diverse Care Providers

Equitable Access

Continuity of Care

LMS + EHR Integrations

Previous

Next

Ready to Expand Access to Care?

Mental Health Outcomes Reveal Impact

At TimelyCare, our mission is to foster student success and improve the health and well-being of campus communities. A key to fulfilling this mission is helping students get better, faster – especially those with severe depression and anxiety symptoms.

TimelyCare users who entered care with severe symptoms on the PHQ-9 or GAD-7 achieved, on average, clinically significant change by their third scheduled counseling or psychiatry visit. Additionally, those who entered care with clinical symptoms on the PHQ-9 or GAD-7, on average, dropped a severity ranking (e.g., moderate to mild) by their third scheduled counseling or psychiatry visit.

77%

of students who sought help through TimelyCare reported mental health improvements

85%

of community college students say they are more likely to remain in classes, improve their grades, and graduate – or all of the above – after using TimelyCare

9 out of 10

students said they would recommend TimelyCare's services

4.95/5 stars

rating for TimelyCare's national network of care providers

Our Commitment to Inclusion

Combatting the Campus Mental Health Crisis

As the campus mental health crisis continues, the need to ensure equitable, on-demand access to care has never been more important. You’ve likely added counselors or expanded resources in some way, but what happens when offices are closed or resources are unavailable? Vulnerable students can end up suffering in silence.

TimelyCare’s diverse care provider network empowers students with confidential, one-on-one support from health care experts who are empathetic to their needs.

4 out of 5

college students say campuses face a full-blown mental health crisis

55%

of students who considered dropping out in 2022 cited emotional stress as the reason they considered leaving – more than any other reason

32%

of non-completers cited mental health issues as a contributing factor for leaving college, 14% said it was the primary reason

2 in 3

students say mental health resources make them more likely to graduate

92%

of Gen Z said that care provided via telehealth was the same or better compared to in-office visits.

#1

Access to virtual counseling and mental health support through a teletherapy or virtual care app is the number one resource students wished their schools offered.
